� FUNCTION DESCRIPTION:
19.1.1 Introduction
This document is the high level SW speci?cation of the NVMY function.
NVMY allows storing and restoring data manipulated by the Engine Control Unit as adaptative values, error
?ags for the diagnosis, and engine environments on several driving cycles in case of failure...
The non volatile data management shall provide:
? a common interface between the aggregates in the ECU and the NVMY function i.e. the mechanism to
access to the memory for writing and reading stored data,
? different services provided to the aggregates,
? a safety data storage
19.1.2 Abbreviations and terms
CRC Cyclic Redundancy Checksum

EEPROM Electrically Erasable Programmable Read Only Memory
NVMY Non Volatile MemorY
FLASH EEPROM emulation means that NVMY data are stored into a ?ash device.
In the rest of this document the term memory means either EEPROM or FLASH EEPROM emulation.
19.1.3 General description
Usually the manager provides the capability to initialise, memorize and restore data. The NVMY manager shall
ensure the NVMY data recording, and also secure the NVMY data integrity.
The NVMY manager shall support:
? a scheduler to handle the priority of the tasks,
? a supervisor, called regularly by the operating system, handles the real time,
? an executor of the services,
? the return of error cases to the others aggregates,
? the initialisation of the data and the integrity of the data in the memory structure.
19.1.4 NVMY system events
Three related system events are de?ned:
? NVMRES: read-out (restore) non volatile data from the memory. It happens before the RST. In case of
error, NVMINI happens afterwards
? NVMINI: initialise the non-volatile data with de?ned default values. It happens after NVMRES and
before the RST in case of error during NVMRES
? NVMSTO: store the non-volatile data into the memory. It happens in a safe ECU mode (ECU shutdown).
By extension, the write "on ?y" functionality uses the same system event.

19.1.5 Hardware constraints
The NVMY manager is hardware independent and shall administrate the NVMY data on EEPROM and/or
FLASH EEPROM emulation.
� EEPROM:
Writing of NVMY data could be done ?in live? (write "on ?y") while the ECU is running. This operation must be
limited in order to save the EEPROM life duration regarding the hardware write/erase cycles.
Also, the application needs to take into account the EEPROM size capability.
� FLASH EEPROM emulation:
Both accesses to ?ash data are available regarding ?ash hardware de?nition:
? One bank: the operating system is blocked while erase/write operation. The write/erase operation has to
ensure that the SW is in a safe ECU mode (shutdown phase). Application has to guaranty that all NVMY
data must be stored at shutdown phase.
? Dual banks: the operating system is not blocked while erase/write operation. There is the possibility to
store NVMY data while applicative SW is running.
Two speci?c ?ash segments are requested (at least).
� Key-on detection during power-latch phase:
NVMY data storage at end of Power Latch can take time (ie if Data Flash is used, erase time can take several
seconds).
Consequently, it can be necessary to detect key-on in NVMY manager. The strategy to apply must be speci?ed
in module "Non Volatile Data Management, con?guration" (key-on detection Yes/No).
If strategy is enabled, a reset will be performed :
? EEPROM device : after end of writing of current channel or set of consistent channels (see paragraph
1.11.1).
? Flash device : after end of writing of the Power Latch block.
� Recommendation:
The writing of NVMY data "on ?y" must be limited to one per ECU cycle in order to save the memory life
duration.
� Pre-emptive operation:
Application must ensure not to perform operation on memory while it is used by the NVMY manager.
19.1.6 Non Volatile Memory - Mechanisms for Data initialization
This section deals with all cases of NVMY data initialisation.
The initialisation consists in initialising data with their default values.
RAM value is initialised. The saved variable value will be stored at next power-latch (or next write if variable is
written "on ?y")
The data sets may be either partially or completely initialised depending on the case.
In addition, we can distinguish 4 kind of initialisation:
? First initialisation
? General initialisation
? Initialisation of groups of channels by API call
? Calibration initialisation (optional, see module "Non volatile data management, con?guration")

NVMY data initialisation is performed during the NVMY RESTORE stage.
If at least one channel must be initialised (whatever the reason), the ?ag LV_NVMY_INIT_REQ is set.
The following diagram depicts all kind of NVMY data initialisation:
19.1.6.1 Initialisation in case of corrupted channel
Basically, this initialisation is requested by the NVMY executor in case of a reading error occurred toward
a single channel. Reading failure can be generated by a hardware failure or an integrity channel problem
(according to the channel attribute con?guration).
19.1.6.2 Initialisation in case of NVMY coherency error
During RESTORE stage, NVMY functionality should ensure that restore data match with Applicative software
functionalities, which are using NVMY data.
NVMY coherency mainly relies on a check at RESTORE stage in order to determine whether NVMY content
(all channels) is compatible or not with applicative software.
Usually, problem may occur if ECU is restarted after it has been previously reprogrammed, because channel
de?nition may have changed in between from one software version to another. Without coherency check, it
may lead Applicative software to run with NVMY data that are not correct, so coherency check is mandatory
before restoring whole NVMY content.
Channels can be con?gured "sensitive" or "not sensitive" to application SW change.
By default, a channel is con?gured to "sensitive" to application SW change.
19.1.6.3 Initialisation in case of "First power-on"
In case of brand new ECU, the initialisation of all channels with their default values is called initialisation "?rst
power-on".
Usually, this kind of initialisation may occur only one time during ECU s lifetime.
After the ?rst power on, the Non Volatile Memory must operate its own initialisation.

So, an important delay may occur between the ?rst power on of the ECU and the availability of the whole
NVMY strategy.
In consequence, all aggregate using NVMY functionality must ?rst wait for the end of this ?rst initialisation.
19.1.6.4 Hard initialisation
Hardware means that channel is initialised with default values within hardware component.
Since these initialisations may be performed during engine running, it saves up writing time at the end of the
power-latch.
This initialisation is only relevant for EEPROM.
19.1.6.5 Groups of channels initialisation by API call
NVMY provides the functionality to initialise group(s) of channel(s), by calling API ACTION_ECME_ClrNvData(IN
<PRM_NR_GRP_SEL>).
The API will cause the initialisation of the channels con?gured in the group(s) selected in PRM_NR_GRP_SEL.
Parameter is a bit?eld, each bit represents a group. Up to 32 groups can be con?gured. Con?guration must be
done in speci?cation "Non Volatile Data Management, con?guration".
1 to 32 bits can be set into the bit?eld, to choose the groups to initialise.
19.1.7 Write "on ?y" request
The NVMY manager provides the functionality to write "on ?y" a single channel into the memory.
The end of a write shall be noti?ed with a call-back function that is speci?ed in the con?guration of the chan-
nel.
19.1.8 Read for Diag request
The NVMY manager provides a functionality to read out a single channel from the memory without 
affecting the applicative aggregate's data.

19.1.9 NVMY status check
NVMY provides to other aggregates an API to check its status : ACTION_ECME_ChkBusy( OUT<PRM_SDR>).
PRM_SDR will inform the caller if NVMY is busy (PRM_SDR = 1) or not (PRM_SDR = 0).
One typical usecase concerns reprogramming, when emulated EEPROM is used : before switching into Boot
software, reprogramming strategy must ensure that NVMY is not busy.
19.1.10 NVMY diagnostics
The non volatile data management offers the possibility to the applicative software to be informed of a request
(restore, write "on-?y" and store) ending status. This can be used to take dedicated action in case of an error.
If activated (see NVMY con?guration part), the end of the request is noti?ed to the applicative software by
a call-back function (see NVMY con?guration part). In this case, a status is available on each NVMY channel
according the used request.

19.1.11 Channels description
This section gives a summary of NVMY features in order to advise you in the way that you de?ne your data
into channels organisation.
Each aggregate that want to use some Non Volatile data must create a channel containing all data to be
saved.
19.1.11.1 Channel organization
The NVMY is divided into channels that physically represent a part of the hardware component.
Each channel is divided into two parts. The ?rst part so-called Header contains the data related to the saving
criteria. In other words, the data that ensures saving data integrity. The second part only contains the saved
data that belongs to the same aggregate.
Basically, the contents of non-volatile memory looks like as follow:

Each aggregate (or function) can de?ne one or several channels depending on its requirements. Nevertheless
two different Aggregates could not share their channel.
If one aggregate uses more than one channel, the aggregate is in charge to ensure the coherency between its
channels.
Nevertheless, for EEPROM device, a strategy is provided by generic solution to ensure coherency between
some channels (optional, see module "Non volatile data management, con?guration"). This strategy is not
needed for Data Flash because the complete Power Latch block coherency is ensured.

Non volatile memory data that should be secured with two different criteria can not share the same channel.
Nevertheless, you may take the strongest criteria in order to group these data.
Default storage is CRC16. If another method is used, it must be explicitly speci?ed in the aggregate?s speci?ca-
tion.
19.1.12 De?nition of variables managed by NVMY
Data managed by Non Volatile Data Management must be de?ned in the speci?cation ?le in which they are
produced as output data with "S" mode.
By default, "S" mode means:
? Channel integrity is covered by checksum CRC16
? Variable is read out from memory at restore event
? Variable is stored into memory at store event
? Channel is "sensitive" to application SW change
? Default value must be de?ned into initialization part
If NVMY data behaviour is different than standard de?nition above, this has to be described in the speci?cation
where the variable is produced.

19.2.1 General con?guration
� General Information
This chapter describes the con?guration of the ECME.
Remark:
The con?guration speci?ed below is also valid for XSECME used in CBoot SW (as far as applicable). The
channel con?guration is shared between both subsystems.
� Function Description
19.2.1.1 Hardware device
NVMY functionality can be ful?lled either by using a EEPROM device or an FLASH device, with EEPROM
emulation.
Specify project device by selecting one line below :
EEPROM
FLASH single bank
FLASH dual bank X
Erase Suspend Mode has to be activated to ful?ll timing requirements for Immobilizer.
19.2.1.2 Supervisor recurrency
This de?nition is used to con?gure the time delay between execution tasks ? e.g. the time delay to start
execution task after the end of the previous one. Time base is 5ms and minimum value will be >= to
5ms.
Value recommended: 40ms in order not to increase the CPU load, SPI bus load...

19.2.1.3 SW version detection
The NVMY manager gives the possibility to choose which reference is used by the NVMY coherency strat-
egy.
By default, the reference corresponds to the ECU SW reference ("ecu_sw_ref").

19.2.1.4 Key-on detection during power-latch phase
During storage phase, key-on can be detected to restart the ECU even if NVMY data storage is not ended.
If ECME_IGK_DETECTION_AT_PWL is NOT 0, the storing of NVMY data can be interrupted by the key turned
on.
If ECME_IGK_DETECTION_AT_PWL is 0, the storing of NVMY data can?t be interrupted.
De?nition Value
ECME_IGK_DETECTION_AT_PWL 0
If activated, constant value NC_ECME_WRITING_ALL_TIMEOUT_IN_NS must be ?lled with:
? EEPROM device : timeout for channel writing time.
If key-on is detected, reset will be performed after end of writing of current channel or set of consistent chan-
nels, or after this time is elapsed (covers SPI communication problem, EEPROM writing problem).
? Data Flash device : time for writing complete Power Latch block.
If key-on is detected, reset will be performed after end of writing of current driving cycle data.
De?nition Value
NC_ECME_WRITING_ALL_TIMEOUT_IN_NS NA
==>In SC8 project, the PWL storage of NVMY data is done in background, while operating system is
still running. Therefore, no explicit IGK detection is required.

In case of IGK ON during storage, the PWLOFF event occurs and the storage is aborted, but the data in
RAM keeps present and can be used by the application. No reset is done in that situation and no delay
occurs. The data in RAM will be further used by application and will be stored into NVMY after the PWL
phase is activated next time.

19.2.1.13 Powerlatch Handling for NVMY
The generic ECME shutdown approach is not used.
To avoid a startup delay, if IGK is switched on during NVMY storage, the PWL data is stored in background.
The storage is aborted in case of PWLOFF event. Potential consistency issues between different ECME
channels need to be handled on application level.
Attention! The PWL storage is done already before the event PWLEND will occur. So the data has to
be ready for storage already after the call of PWLON event or a lock condition has to be set in order to
delay the storage until the data is ready.
Description:
If Powerlatch Phase is activated from Normal Operation (PWLON) or from WAIT state (WT2PWL), ecme_
pwlon() must be called. This interface only sets the PWL lock condition for NVMY.

Lock PWL for NVMY.

If a wakeup occurs at the end of powerlatch (after all activities including ECME/FEE storage and internal
operations have been ?nished and lv_pwl_act goes to 0), ecu_state switches from PWL to WAIT state. If
then IGK is switched on, only the WT2MN event occurs, but not the PWLOFF event, although PWL phase
was aborted. Therefore ECME needs to provide a separate API to set back the PWL storage status. Further
activities are not required, because ECOP ensures that the transition PWL- ->WAIT is only done when there
is no PWL lock condition anymore (and therefore, PWL storage must have been ?nished before).

In the state sequence PWL-WAIT-PWL (wakeup at the end of PWL, but IGK is not switched on in calibrated

19.2.3 ACTION_ECME_WriteOnFly
This action triggers the WriteOnFly operation for the requested channel.
This action is mapped to ecme_nvcmd_write_ch_req().
19.2.4 ACTION_ECME_StoreAllBackground
This action triggers the storage of all channels that would also be stored at end of PWL phase (con?guration
END_PWL). Additionally explicit write requests can be added here. In case of short PWL (if the ?ag lv_inh_
nvmy_save is set), only the required Write on FLY channels will be stored, that are explicitly triggered in the
corresponding branch.
The storage will be done in Background.
The action is mapped to ecme_nvcmd_store_pwl().

19.3.2 Introduction
This document is the high level SW speci?cation of the NVMY function.
First use of NVMY is to allow storing and restoring data manipulated by the Engine Control Unit as adaptative
values, error ?ags for the diagnosis, and engine environments on several driving cycles in case of failure...
It can also be needed by some reprogramming strategies to store/restore some informations during repro-
gramming session, when ECU is running in Boot software.
This minimal implementation is dedicated to this goal.
The non volatile data management shall provide:
? a common interface between the aggregates in the ECU and the NVMY function i.e. the mechanism to
access to the memory for writing and reading stored data,
? different services provided to the aggregates,
? a safe data storage

EEPROM Electrically Erasable Programmable Read Only Memory
NVMY Non Volatile MemorY

FLASH EEPROM emulation means that NVMY data are stored into a ?ash device.
In the rest of this document the term memory means either EEPROM or FLASH EEPROM emulation.
19.3.4 General description
Usually the manager provides the capability to initialise, memorize and restore data. The NVMY manager shall
ensure the NVMY data recording, and also secure the NVMY data integrity.
The minimal NVMY manager shall support:
? Restore of data from NVMY to RAM,
? Write On Fly on data from RAM to NVMY,
? the return of error cases to the others aggregates,
? the initialisation of the data and the integrity of the data in the memory structure.
? XSECME has no access to general Application DATA -
? XSECME has only access to BOOT and ASW Common data
? XSECME is only working in BOOT SW without interrupts enabeld
19.3.5 NVMY system events
Three related system events are de?ned:
? NVMRES: read-out (restore) non volatile data from the memory. It happens before the RST. In case of
error, NVMINI happens afterwards
? NVMINI: initialise the non-volatile data with de?ned default values. It happens after NVMRES and
before the RST in case of error during NVMRES
? NVMSTO: store the non-volatile data into the memory. In Minimal implementation, only the write "on
?y" functionality is supported.

19.3.6 Hardware constraints
The Minimal NVMY manager is developped to work with data saved in FLASH EEPROM emulation, Dual bank
strategy.
� FLASH EEPROM emulation:
Both accesses to ?ash data are available regarding ?ash hardware de?nition:
? One bank: the operating system is blocked while erase/write operation. The write/erase operation has to
ensure that the SW is in a safe ECU mode (shutdown phase). Application has to guaranty that all NVMY
data must be stored at shutdown phase.

This section deals with all cases of NVMY data initialisation.
The initialisation consists in initialising data with their default values.
RAM value is initialised. The saved variable value will be stored at next write if variable is written "on ?y"
The data sets may be either partially or completely initialised depending on the case.
In addition, we can distinguish 4 kind of initialisation:
? First initialisation
? General initialisation

ECME, Non volatile data management implementation
19.3.7.1 Initialisation in case of corrupted channel
Basically, this initialisation is requested by the NVMY executor in case of a reading error occurred toward
a single channel. Reading failure can be generated by a hardware failure or an integrity channel problem
(according to the channel attribute con?guration).
19.3.7.2 Initialisation in case of NVMY coherency error
In full ECME the following is done:
During RESTORE stage, NVMY functionality should ensure that restore data match with Applicative software
functionalities, which are using NVMY data.
NVMY coherency mainly relies on a check at RESTORE stage in order to determine whether NVMY content
(all channels) is compatible or not with applicative software.
Usually, problem may occur if ECU is restarted after it has been previously reprogrammed, because channel
de?nition may have changed in between from one software version to another. Without coherency check, it
may lead Applicative software to run with NVMY data that are not correct, so coherency check is mandatory
before restoring whole NVMY content.
Channels can be con?gured "sensitive" or "not sensitive" to application SW change.
As Minimal ECME is (mainly) dedicated to reprogramming strategies, the saved data which are managed in
Mini ECME must be con?gured "not sensitive" to application SW change.
The Minimal ECME does not take care about NVMY coherency. Channels are read one by one, and channel
integrity is managed individually.
19.3.7.3 Initialisation in case of "First power-on"
First power-on is not speci?cally managed in Minimal ECME. Channels are read, and their consistency is
checked, one by one.
19.3.8 Write "on ?y" request
The NVMY manager provides the functionality to write "on ?y" a single channel into the memory.
The end of a write shall be noti?ed with a call-back function that is speci?ed in the con?guration of the chan-
nel.
19.3.9 Read for Diag request
Read for Diag is not provided by Minimal ECME. Only restore at startup is done.
19.3.10 NVMY status check
Functionality not provided by Minimal ECME
19.3.11 NVMY diagnostics
Functionality not provided by Minimal ECME
19.3.12 Channels description
This section gives a summary of NVMY features in order to advise you in the way that you de?ne your data
into channels organisation.
Each aggregate that want to use some Non Volatile data must create a channel containing all data to be
saved.
19.3.12.1 Channel organization
The NVMY is divided into channels that physically represent a part of the hardware component.

ECME, Non volatile data management implementation
Each channel is divided into two parts. The ?rst part so-called Header contains the data related to the saving
criteria. In other words, the data that ensures saving data integrity. The second part only contains the saved
data that belongs to the same aggregate.
Basically, the contents of non-volatile memory looks like as follow:
Channel A 
Aggr Y set 1CH Header A Aggr X set 1 CH Header B Aggr X set 2 CH Header C 
Channel B Channel C 
Each aggregate (or function) can de?ne one or several channels depending on its requirements. Nevertheless
two different Aggregates could not share their channel.
If one aggregate uses more than one channel, the aggregate is in charge to ensure the coherency between its
channels.
Nevertheless, for EEPROM device, a strategy is provided by generic solution to ensure coherency between
some channels (optional, see module "Non volatile data management, con?guration"). This strategy is not
needed for Data Flash because the complete Power Latch block coherency is ensured.
19.3.12.2 Saving criteria
Data that belongs to the same channel are secured by a single saving criterion taken from the list below:
? CRC 16 : channel integrity is covered by checksum calculation CRC16
                                        
C R C 1 6 A g g re g a te ?s  d a ta c h a n n e l 
c h a n n e l 
h e a d e r 
c h a n n e l d a ta 
 
If the checksum does not ?t with the aggregate?s data, then the channel is declared as corrupted: the
initialization is mandatory.
? MASTER and COPY : Functionality not provided by Minimal ECME
? NONE: Functionality not provided by Minimal ECME
19.3.13 Data encryption/decryption
Minimal ECME provides the possibility for projects to encryp/decrypt NVMY data.
To do so, ECME generic kernel calls hook functions, which are part of the con?gurable part. These functions
then call the project speci?c encryption functions.
The hooks must be speci?ed in module "Non volatile data management, con?guration".
As Minimal ECME operates in foreground mode only, hook functions are also designed to work in foreground
mode.
The encryption/decryption is channelwise con?gurable.
WARNING: The encryption algorithm used by the project must not add data to the original channel (before
encryption): the length of the channel after encryption must be inferior or equal to the length before encryp-
tion.
19.3.14 De?nition of variables managed by NVMY
Data managed by Non Volatile Data Management must be de?ned in the speci?cation ?le in which they are
produced as output data with "S" mode.
By default, "S" mode means:
? Channel integrity is covered by checksum CRC16
? Variable is read out from memory at restore event

� General information:
The NVM Crypt Diagnosis checks:
1. The functionality of the encryption engine.
2. The integrity of the encryption engine by verifying the content of a dedicated instance in the non volatile
memory of the ECU.
3. Whether sample software is programmed on production Hardware.
Depending on the test type, the diagnosis is executed at different times:
1. Each time data is crypted or decrypted.
2. ECU Startup, during read of NVM data.
3. ECU Startup, during read of NVM data
(only active if the hardware criteria is available on the target platform)
It must be ensured internally that direct ERRM access is only done after complete initialization of the ERRM
aggregate. Errors which occur pre ERRM-init must be memorized and set as soon as possible.

� Formula section:
� at reset:
Error detection
If decryption of NVMCrypt Monitor Instance from non volatile memory fails
Then diagnosis ?nished with Session Key error
LV_ERR_NVMCRYPT = 1 /* error is set for this engine run no debounce*/
ERR_SYM_NVMCRYPT = SYM_1
Else If veri?cation of NVMCrypt Monitor Instance is valid
Then diagnosis ?nished without error
LV_ERR_NVMCRYPT = 0 /* error is set for this engine run no debounce*/
ERR_SYM_NVMCRYPT = NO_SYM
Else If invalid NVMCrypt Monitor Instance can be repaired
Then diagnosis ?nished without error (repair instance)
LV_ERR_NVMCRYPT = 0 /* error set for this engine run no debounce*/
ERR_SYM_NVMCRYPT = NO_SYM
Else diagnosis ?nished with NVMCrypt integrity error
LV_ERR_NVMCRYPT = 1 /* error set for this engine run no debounce*/
ERR_SYM_NVMCRYPT = SYM_2
Endif
Endif
Endif
� asynchronous:
Error detection for session key error
If Encryption or Decryption fails (due to session key calculation error)
Then set Session Key error
LV_ERR_NVMCRYPT = 1 /* error is set for this engine run no debounce*/
ERR_SYM_NVMCRYPT = SYM_1
Endif
Error detection for sample SW on Production HW error
If Sample SW on Production HW
Then set Sample SW on Production HW error
LV_ERR_NVMCRYPT = 1 /* error is set for this engine run no debounce*/
ERR_SYM_NVMCRYPT = SYM_3
Endif

## Function
The diagram describes the initialization process of Non-Volatile Memory (NVMY) data within an Electronic Control Unit (ECU) during the NVMY RESTORE stage. It details various scenarios that trigger the need for NVMY data initialization and how they are handled.

## Inputs
*   ECU Start-up
*   Channel data from hardware component
*   Integrity check/hardware failure result for the channel
*   NVMY coherency error request
*   Tuning initialization request
*   "Is it the first NVMY initialization?" (Boolean)

## Outputs
*   Channel INITIALIZATION (Initialization occurs)
*   Channel is RESTORED (No initialization occurs)

## Logic Flow

1.  **ECU Start-up:** The process begins when the ECU starts up.
2.  **Read out channel from hardware component:** The system reads data from the hardware component associated with a specific channel in the NVMY.
3.  **Is channel corrupted?:**  The system checks if the read channel data is corrupted, due to a hardware failure or integrity check.
    *   **Yes:** If the channel is corrupted, it proceeds to step 4.
    *   **No:** If the channel is not corrupted, it proceeds to step 5.
4.  **Is it the first NVMY initialization?:** Check if the NVMY is being initialized for the first time (first power-on scenario).
    *   **Yes:** If it is the first initialization, perform **Channel INITIALIZATION.**
    *   **No:** If it is *not* the first initialization, perform **Channel INITIALIZATION.** (General Init)
5.  **Is an initialization requested by NVMY coherency error?:** The system checks if there's a coherency error between the NVMY data and the application software.
    *   **Yes:** If a coherency error exists, it proceeds to step 4.
    *   **No:** If no coherency error exists, it proceeds to step 6.
6.  **Is an initialization requested by tuning initialization?:** The system checks if a tuning initialization is needed.
    *   **Yes:** If a tuning initialization is needed, perform **Channel INITIALIZATION.** (Calibration init)
    *   **No:** If a tuning initialization is not needed, the **Channel is RESTORED** without initialization.

## Function

The document describes the functionality of the `ecme_nvcmd_store_pwl` function, which is responsible for triggering the storage of ECME (Error Code Memory Environment) channels in the PWL (Power-down Write Last) area. The type of PWL (normal or short) determines the storage process. It also describes the ECU state transitions and the ECME/FEE calls associated with them.

## Inputs

*   `GET_lv_inh_nvmy_save()`: A boolean flag indicating whether to store nothing in short PWL or to store data.
*   ECME channels: Channels that are triggered to be stored in PWL
*   PWL channels: Channels to be stored in PWL during normal operation
*   FLY channels: Project specific FLY channels that shall be stored at end of PWL

## Outputs

*   Storage of ECME channels in PWL: This involves writing the current values of specified ECME channels to a non-volatile memory location.
*   ECU state transitions: changes in the ECU’s operation mode, like moving from WAIT to PWL, etc.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Initialization:** The `ecme_nvcmd_store_pwl` function is triggered, indicating a request to store ECME channels in PWL.
2.  **PWL Type Determination:** The function determines the type of PWL being used (normal or short).
3.  **Conditional Storage:**
    *   **IF `GET_lv_inh_nvmy_save()` is TRUE:** Nothing is stored in short PWL. This suggests that certain conditions might prevent the storage of data in the short PWL configuration.
    *   **ELSE (if `GET_lv_inh_nvmy_save()` is FALSE):**
        *   Handle first start detection of ECME
        *   Trigger the storage of PWL channels.
        *   Trigger the storage of project specific FLY channels at the end of the PWL process.
4. **ECU State Transitions:**
    * The state transition overview shows the possible states of the ECU: MN (normal operation), WAIT, PWL (Power-down Write Last).

*   Trigger the storage of project specific FLY channels at the end of the PWL process.
4. **ECU State Transitions:**
    * The state transition overview shows the possible states of the ECU: MN (normal operation), WAIT, PWL (Power-down Write Last).
    * The state transitions are triggered by specific events:
        *   PWLON: Transition from WAIT to PWL or from MN to PWL
        *   WT2PWL: Transition from WAIT to PWL
        *   PWLOFF: Transition from PWL to MN
        *   PWL2WT: Transition from PWL to WAIT. No ECME/FEE call to be inserted in hook routine.
        *   WT2MN: Transition from WAIT to MN.
    *   Associated with each state transition event is an ECME/FEE function call:
        *   `ecme_pwlon()`: called when PWLON or WT2PWL occur.
        *   `ecme_pwloff()`: called when PWLOFF occurs.
        *   `ecme_wt2mn0`: called when WT2MN occurs.

## Function
The diagram illustrates the NVMY (Non-Volatile Memory) data initialization process during the NVMY RESTORE stage within an automotive ECU (Electronic Control Unit). It describes the steps taken to either restore previously stored data or initialize the memory channel.

## Inputs
*   ECU Startup signal.
*   Channel data from the hardware component.
*   Channel corruption status (determined by integrity check or hardware failure).
*   Initialization request status (triggered by tuning initialization).

## Outputs
*   Channel RESTORED (Data is read from memory and valid).
*   Channel INITIALIZATION (Data is overwritten with initial/default values).

## Logic Flow
1.  **ECU Startup:** The process begins when the ECU starts up.
2.  **Read out channel from hardware component:** The channel data is read out from the non-volatile memory.
3.  **Is channel corrupted?:** An integrity check or hardware failure check is performed to determine if the channel data is corrupted.
    *   If the channel is corrupted ("yes"), the process proceeds to "Channel INITIALIZATION".
    *   If the channel is not corrupted ("no"), the process proceeds to the next step.
4.  **Is an initialization requested by tuning initialization?:** Checks if an initialization request has been triggered by some tuning process.
    *   If an initialization is requested ("yes"), the process proceeds to "Channel INITIALIZATION".
    *   If an initialization is not requested ("no"), the process proceeds to "Channel is RESTORED".
5.  **Channel INITIALIZATION:** The memory channel is initialized, overwriting any existing data with default values.
6.  **Channel is RESTORED:** The data on the memory channel is valid, and it has been read out and is ready to be used.
7.  **NVMY RESTORE stage:** All described actions occur within the NVMY RESTORE stage.
